Award.AwardTitle: Resolving systematic uncertainty in Streptomyces by interpreting their evolution and biogeography through the prism of horizontal gene exchange
Award.AbstractNarration:
Ubiquitous in soils, streptomycetes are bacteria from which we derive more than half of all clinically useful bioactive compounds. However, we lack a coherent taxonomic framework to explain the ecological and evolutionary significance of antibiotic production in the genus. Horizontal gene exchange is hypothesized to be profound within certain bacterial lineages and is expected to explain taxonomic challenges in Streptomyces. This project will examine genetic diversity in the genus Streptomyces and the evolutionary forces that generate these patterns. The project is transformational in that it examines a new paradigm for understanding the evolutionary history of streptomycetes. This new paradigm should have a dramatic impact on our understanding of microbial evolution and the evolution of antibiotic production.

Our limited knowledge of the evolutionary history of Streptomyces bacteria has impeded progress in understanding the evolution of antibiotics. Information on the biogeography and evolution of Streptomyces should promote development of rational sampling strategies for discovering diverse strains and novel bioactive compounds. This project includes a novel outreach effort for high school science teachers and students, allowing them to participate in our research efforts through sampling of their local soils. A postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student, and undergraduates will also receive training and mentorship in this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined patterns of biogeography and genomic diversity within the bacterial genus Streptomyces. Streptomycetes are ubiquitous in soils and more than half of all clinically useful bioactive compounds originate within the genus Streptomyces. Remarkable effort has been directed towards elucidating the genetics and developmental biology of these bacteria. Yet many mysteries remain, not the least of which is that we still lack a coherent taxonomic framework for the genus, and a robust framework to explain the ecological and evolutionary significance of antibiotic production.

 

This project performed genetic characterization of thousands of Streptomyces strains representing hundreds of species. We isolated strains from sites across the USA to generate a geographically explicit isolate collection composed of >1,000 Streptomyces strains. These new isolates were examined in relation to strains available in public culture collections. We identified more than 100 distinct populations in our isolate collection, half of which have never before been described. We have already described and named one new species from the collection and work is ongoing to name additional new species which we have discovered. We also described and validated taxonomic markers for use in Streptomyces and this will make it easier to discover new species of Streptomyces in the future. We preformed genomic analysis of strains from multiple populations in order to explore their evolutionary dynamics at regional spatial scales. As a result we discovered a latitudinal diversity gradient in North American Streptomyces and our evidence suggests that this biogeographical pattern is the result of post-glacial range expansion. These results suggest that historical range expansion events could provide an evolutionary mechanism to explain patterns of genomic diversity in the genus, including ancient patterns of gene exchange between species. These results provide new and exciting insights into the forces that govern microbial biogeography and microbial evolution.

 

The project contributed to the training of 1 PhD student, 3 undergraduate students, and 1 postdoctoral scholar. In addition, the project resulted in 9 invited seminar presentations, 8 conference presentations presented at national and international scientific meetings, and 7 papers published in peer reviewed journals.
